, is a tiny Inuvialuit village on the Arctic Ocean in the extreme north of
two to three times a day from
, which in turn can be reached by First Air

A 100-mile ice road on the Mackenzie River connects Tuktoyaktuk to Inuvik in the winter only (Jan-Apr).  For the rest of the year, flying is the only way in, although an all-season road is in the planning stages (as of April 2012).

While it is easy to get around on foot in the town, taking a snowmobile to the store or out on the land is very common. The weather is very hard on vehicles so if you decide to drive be prepared to let your vehicle warm up for a long time in the winter months. Sometimes there is a taxi service available. For trips out on the land or to the airport via the ice road, there are people who will drive you out, such as the charter van for Ookpik Tours.

value: .   This freezer was dug in 1963 in the permafrost underneath the town and has been in use as a permanent fridge ever since. Very eerie but amazing. Used by locals to store meat collected during hunts. There are 19 rooms in total, divided into three "hallways." Strangely, it is coolest in the ice house during the summer months, but in the winter it warms up and meat is taken out to prevent molding.
content=Pingos are domes of earth-covered ice found only in the high arctic. There are over a thousand in and around Tuk. Get to the pingos by snowmobile. Hike to the top and toboggan down!

content=During the cold war, the American and Canadian governments created a Distant Early Warning (DEW) system in case the Russians attacked via the Arctic. One of the stations is in Tuk. You can't miss it, it looks like a few giant snowballs.
content=Here you will find the historical roots of Tuk and look out on the Beaufort Sea.
content=Find this colourful route marker near The Point. Installed in 2000.
content=There are a couple reconstructed sod houses in Tuk that you can step inside of. Historical flashback
content=Sign up with a local guide to find caribou, polar bear, beluga whale, fox, wolverine, etc.
content=For a few weeks in the summer there is a swimming pool open in Tuk. Otherwise, there is another swimming pool in nearby Inuvik.
content=This takes place in Tuk around the middle of April. A large cultural festival full of games, food and fun. Jamboree King and Queen competition.
content=Regular games night at Kitti Hall. Checkers, chess, and card games with the locals.
content=Build an igloo, see the pingos, hunt for polar bear, experience Tuk with a local guide.
address=Intersection of Mangilaluk Drive & Beaufort Drive
content=Groceries, post office, tools, clothes, electronics, toys etc.

content=Every once and awhile, the fruit man pulls his semitrailer into Tuk. You can purchase fruit, vegetables, among many other foods, often a bit cheaper and fresher than what is sold at Stanton's. He only stays for a little while so act fast!

. This is the closest place to go for restaurants, hotels, etc. Under 3 hours to drive.
